That depends what you mean by "undo". If you simply mean that you did `] activate .`, and you want to go back to the default environment, simply do `] activate` (without anything after `activate`).

If you want to destroy an environment you created, just delete the `Project.toml` and `Manifest.toml` files.

text: Note also that instantiating a new environment with `] activate .` will _not_ create a `Project.toml` file until you add at least one package to that environment. So if you typed `] activate .` by mistake, doing `] activate` immediately afterwards, or simply closing the REPL, will be as if you never instantiated the environment in the first place.

text: Indeed. That's because the Julia package system tries to cache as much as possible, so download and compile actions only happen when they really need to. So two environments that use the same package version actually use the same package.

text: It's better than Python environments that require a separate copy of each package, so you end up with twenty copies of the same Pandas version on your disk.
